description:
​

CHaMP is designed as a Columbia River basin-wide habitat status and trends monitoring program built around a single protocol with a programmatic approach to data collection and management (RM&E Workgroup 2010). CHaMP will result in the collection and analysis of systematic habitat status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide habitat conditions. When coupled with biological response indicators, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies. This program will be integrated with ongoing Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Program (PNAMP) recovery planning efforts and will be part of the collaborative process across Columbia Basin fish management agencies and tribes and other state and federal agencies that are monitoring anadromous salmonids and/or their habitat. The implementation of CHaMP will characterize stream responses to watershed restoration and/or management actions in at least one population within each steelhead and spring Chinook Major Population Group (MPG) which have, or will have, “fish-in” and “fish-out” monitoring (identified in RPA 50.6), thereby meeting the requirements of RPA 56.3, RPA 57, and RPA 3. CHaMP was designed to deliver trends in habitat indicators and requires that monitoring occurs for three cycles of a sampling panel (see section 1.6), at least 9 years.

Lemhi’s primary objective was to estimate habitat condition for the Lemhi subbasin, and estimate the habitat condition in each of 18 priority drainages (see strata list). The Lemhi status and trends sampling design consisted of 45 unique sites sampled over three years (the standard CHaMP design) and was supplemented with 72 sites funded by the ISEMP program.  The Steelhead (Snake River Basin DPS) - Lemhi River and  the Chinook Salmon (Snake River Spring/Summer-run ESU) - Lemhi River were the populations of interest.  The original rationale was to allocate annual sites across the smaller tributaries to get a broad coverage of the diversity of habitat types, and use more rotating panel sites in the larger tributaries.

2017 Design Updates:

Programmatic changes to the CHaMP field sampling efforts triggered changing all annual panel sites to rotating panel sites. The following sites were shifted: 

CBW05583-035679 (annual-Agency to RP1-Agency, Use order 1 to 1)

CBW05583-254415 (annual Big Eightmile to RP2-Big Eightmile, Use order 1 to 1)

BigSprings-5 (annual Big Springs to RP3-Big Springs, Use order 1 to 1)

CBW05583-001487 (annual Big Timber to RP1-Big Timber, Use order 1 to 1)

CBW05583-049615 (annual Canyon to RP2-Canyon, Use order 1 to 1)

CBW05583-048559 (annual Hayden to RP3-Hayden, Use order 1 to 1)

CBW05583-026031 (annual Lemhi upper mainstem to RP2 -Lemhi upper mainstem, Use order 1 to 1)

Additionally, Site 050639 (Hawley-RP1 is not perennial and will be rejected and replaced with another Hawley site).  

A Lee Creek Extended site (different GRTS design) CBW05583-353711 will be rejected as non-anadromous and effort will instead be put into the Lower Mainstem Lemhi stratum (RP1).  

Block counts to adjust for all changes listed above were made, along with Use Orders.  

2016 Design Updates:  

There were no changes to the study design.  The 2015 design was registered to cm.org

2015 Sample Design Update Notes:

All core CHaMP designs were updated to accommodate effort that will go towards the 10% repeat design for CHaMP.   The design update will result in 3 annual sites from the active design (e.g. 2014) and move one to each rotating panel.  This will result in a net freeing of 2 visits each year that can be used to revisit 2 sites.  This change preserves the annual sites within the design and adjusts the frequency of sampling.  2 sites slated for sampling in the current year (e.g. 2015) will be randomly selected for repeat sampling. Strata were selected randomly for the Lemhi since no strata have >1 annual site per strata.  

Sites moved from annual to rotating panels included:

CBW05583-207711, Bohannon, Use Order 1 to Rotating Panel 1, Use Order 1

CBW05583-064351, Kenney, Use Order 1 to Rotating Panel 2, Use Order 1

LEM00002-00001D, Little Springs, Use Order 1 to Rotating Panel 3, Use Order 1. Note that I believe although this site is not a 'CBW' master sample point, that the original design included these opportunistic sites because the Little Springs stratum is so small.  

1/23/17: During the review of 2016 site evaluations we found site 440159 in a Wimpey Extra block was sampled in 2014 but not moved to the appropriate panel.  We moved sites 440159 and 125791 (also evaluated for RP1 replacement) to RP1 Wimpey for both the 2014 and 2015 designs.  

2014 Sample Design Update Notes:

Sampling was reduced to 25 sites/year due to a decrease in ISEMP funding for habitat sampling in the Lemhi.  In previous years, ISEMP supplemented the base CHaMP habitat sampling.  

All 11 annual sites will be kept and the first use order site within each sub-watershed for each rotating panel will be kept. In smaller watersheds, there will not be an annual sample.  This will result in 3-4 sites sampled per watershed across the 3 year CHaMP panel rotation.  

​​Strata updates in 2014:

1) The following sub-watersheds will be dropped due to low fish densities, low priority status or a low likelihood they will ever be reconnected.

  • Beaver Valley Creek (Hayden)
  • Little Eightmile Creek
  • Pattee Creek
  • Mill Creek
  • Eighteenmile Creek
  • Texas Creek

 

2) The Lemhi Mainstem will be split into two strata: Upper Lemhi Mainstem (above Hayden Creek) and Lower Lemhi Mainstem (below Hayden Creek).  Existing CHaMP sites that have been previously sampled will still be sampled in these areas as per the sample plan outlined in #1.

3) Almost all sampling will take place at a subset of existing sites, except for a new site needed in Wimpey Creek and new GRTS draws for Lee Creek and Pratt Creeks, which were not previously sampled in 2011-2013.  The GRTS draws for these two strata will be described in separate Designs in the Sample Designer.

4) Note that the original GRTS use order was used to prioritize the top site in each Rotating Panel, ignoring the public/private designation.

2013 Sample Design Update Notes:

​4 sites were added to the 2013 Lemhi IMW design that were sampled as 'MOCK' sites in 2012.  This did not affect the status and trend sampling design and no additional GRTS sites were drawn.

​2012 Sample Design Notes:

The original rationale was to allocate annual sites across the smaller tributaries to get a broad coverage of the diversity of habitat types, and use more rotating panel sites in the larger tributaries .  In 2012, this rationale was shifted and annual sites were increased in Hayden and the Lemhi mainstem.  The Withington drainage was removed from the survey due to landowner rejections.  A few sites were shifted among panels, but no new sites were drawn using the GRTS spsurvey function.  Site changes included:

  • Rotating panel 1 - Hayden-Private only had 1 site in the block, so the first 'Extra' site in Hayden-Private (CBW05583-479663) was moved to Rotating Panel 1.
  • Rotating panel 2 -Lemhi Mainstem site CBW005583-026031 was moved to the annual panel.
  • Rotating panel 1- Hayden site CBW005583-028079 was moved to the annual panel, making two annual Hayden sites
  • Rotating panel 1 - Hayden Creek CBW005583-029103 was moved to the annual panel making three annual Hayden sites

 

Rejected annual sites are listed below--these sites were left in their original panels but were replaced as needed with new sites in 2012

  • Lee Creek CBW005583-385487 annual, but access denied.
  • Little Eightmile CBW005583-510383 annual but access denied
  • Wimpy CBW005583-007007 annual, but access denied. This site is a legacy site sampled as part of the first GRTS design.
  • Withington CBW005583-079711annual but access denied.

  ​

2011 Sample Design Notes:

The Lemhi mainstem and each of the priority drainages were considered separate strata in the design process.  Two priority drainages, Little Springs and Big Springs, were not represented in the CBW master sample, so the GRTS algorithm (in the R library ‘spsurvey’) was used to select sites from a 1:24K Hydrography for these two drainages.   Ownership was also used for strata on champmonitoring.org but was not used in the GRTS site selection process. To best support the need for oversample sites, a block of 'Extra' sites for each priority watershed was generated that supported the oversample needs of all panels.  This was done when there were too few sites to allocated as oversamples to individual panels.  

The general design structure was an annual panel and three panels set up on a three year cycle.  Fifteen unique sites will be “annual”; remainder will be allocated to the 3-yr. panels, 1/3 per year, for a total of 49 sites sampled per year (15 annual; 34 rotating panel).  

The R code describes how each stratum’s sample was selected, incorporating relevant legacy sites for that stratum.

Master sample GRTS Input file: Lemhi_MS_20110616.txt

Legacy sample GRTS Input file: Lemhi_Legacy_20110615.txt

Final design file: Design file: Lemhi.design.6.17.2011.csv

R code: Lemhi Design.6.15.r

Strat.panel function version: Stevens.strat.panel6.r

Design Documentation Files:

Lemhi_DesignFiles.zip
targetPopulation:
COPY:

In 2011, Sites were selected based on the wadable, anadromous area of the NHDPlus hydrography and Intrinsic Potential hydrography (Northwest Fisheries Science Center) that were Strahler order >1 and within priority watersheds or the wadable portion of the Lemhi mainstem.  The frame was further refined by Quantitative Consultants, Inc.  to exclude areas upstream of the last site at which steelhead were found in the 2009-2010 fish sampling efforts in the subbasin.  

There were no updates to the frame in 2012 or 2013.

In 2014, the frame was expanded to include Pratt Creek and additional mileage in Lee Creek.  The Lemhi Mainstem was also split into 'Upper' and 'Lower' sections (upper=above Hayden Creek, lower=below Hayden Creek).  The frame was reduced to exclude Texas, Little EIghtmile, Mill, Eighteenmile, Pattee, and Bear Valley Creeks.

There were no changes to the frame in 2015.

GIS Frame file:   The frame hydrography and strata lengths/locations can be downloaded from the following link: 

Lemhi_Frame.zip
title: Lemhi Watershed Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) in 2017
